Ð Ð¾Ñ?Ñ?Ð¸Ð¸AGREEMENT BETWEEN THE GOVERNMENT OF RUSSIAN FEDERATION AND THE GOVERNMENT OF REPUBLIC OF BELARUS ON FREE TRADE(November 13, 1992) The Government of the Russian Federation and the Government of the Republic of Belarus, hereafter referred to as the Contracting Parties,
guided by the provisions of the Treaty between the Russian Federation and the Republic of Belarus, signed on December 18, 1990,
taking into consideration the multilateral Agreement on Co-operation in the Area of Foreign Trade Activities as of May 15, 1992,
taking into consideration the Agreement on Co-ordination of Work on Issues Related to Export Control of Raw Materials, Equipment, Technologies and Services Which Can Be Used to Create Weapons of Mass Destruction and Missiles for Delivery Thereof as of June 26, 1992,
striving to develop trade and economic cooperation between the Russian Federation and the Republic of Belarus based upon equality and mutual benefits,
based upon the sovereign right of each State to conduct independent foreign economic policy,
aiming at fostering economic activities, providing full employment, increasing productivity and rational use of resources,
striving to facilitate harmonious development and growth of international trade, elimination of barriers on its development,
have agreed on the following:

1. Contracting Parties shall not apply customs duties, taxes and charges having equivalent impact on exportation and (or) importation of goods originating from the customs territory of one of Contracting Parties and destined for the customs territory of the other Contracting Party. Exceptions to this trade regime on agreed nomenclature of goods shall be formalized by separate Protocol or Agreement, annual which shall be an integral part of this Agreement.
2. For the purposes of this Agreement, and for its effective term, goods originating from the territories of Contracting Parties shall be deemed to be:
completely produced in the territory of the Contracting Party; or
having been processed on the territory of the Contracting Party by utilizing raw materials, materials and components of third country origin and having changed its classification under the Harmonized System of Commodity Description and Coding of goods in at least one of the first four digits due to this processing;
produced with the use of raw materials and components listed in subparagraph "b" raw materials, materials and components under the condition that their total cost does not exceed a fixed proportion of the export price of commodities sold.
Detailed rules of origin of goods shall be coordinated by the Contracting Parties and included in a separate document that shall become an integral part of this Agreement.

Each of the Contracting Parties shall not permit the re-export of goods, relative to the export of which the other Contracting Party, where these goods originate from, applies measures of tariff and (or) nontariff regulation. The Parties shall exchange the list of goods, to which are applied the measures of tariff and nontariff regulation.
Re-export of such goods may be made only with a written consent and on the terms set by the authorized agency of the country of origin of the said goods. In case of failure to comply with this provision, the Contracting Party whose interests have been affected shall be entitled to unilaterally take measures on regulating the export of such goods to the territory of the other State that permitted the unsanctioned re-export. In case of re-export of such goods the State, from which territory these goods originate from, has the right to claim for compensation of losses.
For the purposes of this Article, re-export shall mean export of goods, originated from the customs territory of one of the Contracting Parties, by another Contracting Party beyond the customs territory of the former, in order to export them to a third country.

The Contracting Parties shall on a regular basis exchange information on customs issues, including customs statistics in its full. Corresponding authorized authorities of the Contracting Parties shall coordinate the procedure for exchanging such information.

1. The Contracting Parties will endeavor to bring together the levels of customs duty rates applied in trade with third countries and for these purposes have agreed to conduct regular consultations.
2. The Contracting Parties shall inform each other of all exceptions to the current state rules on customs tariffs.

For the purposes of applying measures of tariff and non-tariff regulation in the bilateral economic relations, statistical information exchange, and for carrying out customs procedures, the Contracting Parties agreed to use the unified, nine-digit Commodity Nomenclature of Foreign Economic Activities (CN FEA), based upon the Harmonized Commodity Description and Coding System and Combined Tariffs and Statistics Nomenclature of the Eurasian economic community. For their own needs Contracting Parties may expend this Commodity Nomenclature beyond the nine digits if necessary.
Introduction of the reference original of the Commodity Nomenclature is carried out on a mutually agreed basis through the existing representations in the relevant international organizations.
Contracting Parties agreed not to accord export or other subsidies to enterprises, that are on their territories, if such subsidies have as a result violation of fair competition conditions.

The Contracting Parties agree that the adherence to the principle of freedom of transit is the major condition for achieving goals of this Agreement and a substantial element in the process of their integration into the system of international division of labour and cooperation.
Thereupon each Contracting Party shall provide unimpeded transit through its territory for goods originating from the customs territory of the other Contracting Party and (or) third countries and destined for the customs territory of the other Contracting Party or any third country, and shall supply exporters, importers, and carriers with all facilities and services available and necessary for ensuring transit on terms not worse than those granted to national exporters (importers) or carriers, or exporters, importers or carriers of any third state.
Transit tariffs for all types of transportation, including tariffs for loading and unloading operations, shall be economically justified.

With the goal of pursuing coordinated policy of export control in relation to third countries, the Contracting Parties shall establish an Inter-State Coordination Council on Export Control consisting of the heads of national bodies of export control in composition of the heads of national state bodies of export control, which functions shall include the approval of common control check lists, examination of cases of violation of export control requirements and elaboration of proposals to introduce or to eliminate sanctions.

Provisions of this Agreement shall replace the provisions of agreements concluded earlier by the Contracting Parties insofar as the latter are incompatible or identical with the former or identical to them. The Contracting Parties will instruct their competent authorities to prepare an appropriate protocol on this issue.

Nothing in this Agreement shall prevent the Contracting Parties to exercise relations, which shall not contradict the goals and terms of this Agreement with the States, which are not parties to this Agreement, as well as with their associations and international organizations.
Disputes between the Contracting Parties in relation to interpretation or application of provisions of this Agreement shall be resolved by means of negotiations.

To achieve the goals of this Agreement and to elaborate recommendations for improving trade and economic cooperation between the two countries, the Contracting Parties have agreed to establish a joint Russian-Belorussian commission.

Contracting Parties have agreed that the Russian Federation may establish its trade representation in the Republic of Belarus, and the Republic of Belarus may establish its trade representation in the Russian Federation. The legal status of these trade representations, their functions and residence will be agreed by the Contracting Parties in a separate agreement.
Any state, under the condition that the Contracting Parties will approve that, may accede to this Agreement on terms, which would be agreed between the acceding State and the Contracting Parties.
The integral part of this Agreement is the Protocol on the exceptions from the free trade regime, which the Parties shall sign until 1992.

This Agreement becomes effective upon exchange of notices of completion by the Contracting Parties of intra-state procedures necessary for its entry into force and will remain in force prior twelve months from the date of written notification by one Contracting Party of its termination to the other Contracting Party.

Done in the city of Moscow, November 13, 1992 in two originals, each in Russian and Belorussian, both texts being equally authentic.
(Signatures)
